on that note, a lot of the "oh it's unintentionally funny bc we modern audiences know who dracula is as THE vampire" seem to forget that contemporary readers knew what like. 
horror stories
 were. I'm not gonna pretend to know anything about how prevalent/popular vampire mythos was in 1897, but they would know this whole thing is building up to something, that the locals knows something Jonathan doesn't and that they most likely have genuine grounds for concern.
I'm saying I wouldn't be surprised if contemporary audiences reading dracula reacted much in the same way we do with horror films: why the FUCK would you investigate the odd noises coming from the CLEARLY haunted house oh my god?? -> WHY in the name of GOD would you not realise Something Is Up with the count my dude the whole vibe is OFF

Is it too early in Dracula Daily to mention 
The Route of Ice and Salt
, the book written from the perspective of the (gay, angsty, problematic) captain of the 
Demeter
? 
It’s by Mexican author José Luis Zárate. The book may not be everyone’s cup of tea, but I thought it was beautiful. And it’s worthwhile to read queer authors from outside the literary bubble of the Anglosphere. Relatively few non-English books get translated into English, given the state of the publishing industry, let alone queer ones.

New day, new Dracula, new historical context!
Hampton’s Court was a royal residence in London built in the 16th century and occupied by a string of kings and queens starting with Henry VIII and ending with George II. During Queen Victoria’s reign, it was refurbished, and open to the public for tours starting around 1849. 
Assuming Jonathan is a contemporary of the era Dracula was published in - the 1890s - he could easily have visited (which reminds me of a mistake I made last post- since it’s the 90s, Dracula is Edwardian, not Victorian, though Queen Victoria wouldn’t die til 1901. But the fashion period is Edwardian. Adjust ur canary accordingly)
The “servants bell” Jonathan looks for and misses would be a bell in a fancy rope that would ring a connected bell in the downstairs servants’ quarters, alerting staff that someone in his room needed assistance. It’s VERY strange that there isn’t one, given Jonathan’s observations of Dracula’s visible wealth (tapestries, castle). In this era a house like this could only be maintained properly by a full staff. Even though Drac is the only resident, there would still be a cook, butler, housekeeper, footman, driver, and several maids-of-all-work. Their absence is conspicuous, except to Jonathan, who as an upper class Englishman automatically disregards the presence or absence of servants.
The “red” and “blue” books mentioned are diplomatic anthologies. England’s famous 
Blue Book
, dating to the 17th century, is a compilation of diplomatic correspondence and seems to have been annually or semi-annually published, allowing readers some transparency of government. The red book specifically I couldn’t find in my lunch break, but I suspect a similar premise.
Bradshaw’s Guide, as others have posted abt, is a combination railway timetable and travel guide, first produced in the 1830s. Dracula seems to be very thorough in studying English ways…
The mention of the ‘patronymic’ is a reference to Jonathan’s surname. A patronymic strictly speaking references a name as in the Icelandic style, with “son” or “daughter” appended to the father’s first name, but as England does hand down last names patrilineally, through the father, I think this is probably still correct usage. I have no idea if it’s true that Transylvanians/Romanians put the surname first.

i really want everyone to appreciate that part of the horror genre back in the 1800s was the suspense that came from reading second hand accounts of stories and/or unreliable narrators. dracula, frankenstein, edgar allan poe, dr jekyll and mr hyde and hp lovecraft all have this. the protagonist either reads diary entries made by the victim, observes the victim from afar or listens to an old crazy man recounting the events. lt was scary because you didnt know who you can trust to speak the truth and you werent there to confirm it. in the case of dracula you dont know if you can rely on jonathan recounting the story faithfully

body:
are you aware of what you’re putting me through right now tumblr? are you even AWARE? i grew up in a small seaside town called Whitby. Oh, never heard of it, well you WILL because it’s where a bunch of the action in your beloved Dracula is held. 
ARE YOU AWARE OF WHAT ITS LIKE TO GROW UP IN THE PLACE DRACULA WAS SET???
all we ever DO is talk about dracula! I worked at the abbey and i learnt so MUCH history to do tour guides and nobody ever wanted to talk about it! they just wanted to talk about dracula! we have goth weekends where people come to whitby to dress up as goths! My primary school and both my secondary schools studied dracula in depth. There is a ‘dracula experience’ and it is NOT good but everyone and their mother wants to go to it when they come visit you. We had to put on dracula plays! we had to see dracula decorations! every b&b is dracula themed! we did a school trip as children to one of the dracula themed hotels in the town because everyone was obsessed with it! There are big dogs and people make dracula jokes! I used to play in the dracula grave yard after my campanology sessions and everyone just wanted to play dracula! 
And I RAN AWAY. I left that life behind! I moved out of that town so nobody could ever say that stupid vampires name to me again!
But now it is like I cannot escape the hero’s call except the hero’s call is that STUPID BOOK. It won’t leave me alone. Will I ever be free? I cannot even be free on this website. I am doomed to dracula, haunted by him. I am crying. I am screaming. Look what you’ve done tumblr

waiting for Jonathan Harker to tell me about his day

If there were any one to talk to I could bear it, but there is no one. I have only the Count to speak with, and he!—I fear I am myself the only living soul within the place.
So up till now everyone's been gently making fun of Jonathan for plowing right through the red flags, but he's really quite quick on the uptake.  Remember, he lives in a world with no concept of vampires.  For Jonathan, a vampire is a black swan.  There is no genre to be savvy about.  And despite that, it takes him barely four days to come to the conclusion that Dracula is not human.  (Okay, he gets some pretty big clues in the last 24 hours, but still.)
When the Count saw my face, his eyes blazed with a sort of demoniac fury, and he suddenly made a grab at my throat. I drew away, and his hand touched the string of beads which held the crucifix. It made an instant change in him, for the fury passed so quickly that I could hardly believe that it was ever there.
I'm loving all the little differences from current vampire lore.  Dracula's not described as recoiling from the crucifix here; it just makes him able to control his bloodlust.
Ah, young sir, the Szekelys—and the Dracula as their heart's blood, their brains, and their swords—can boast a record that mushroom growths like the Hapsburgs and the Romanoffs can never reach. The warlike days are over. Blood is too precious a thing in these days of dishonourable peace; and the glories of the great races are as a tale that is told."
So do we think Dracula leaving out the House of Hanover is being polite to his English guest, or is that just Stoker displaying British Imperial exceptionalism?  (Also, I see Dracula's starting with his dual literal and metaphorical blood talk.)

body:
one thing that I think is specifically good for 
me 
about the dracula daily experience is that...I’m a very fast reader, and I’m prone to reading through books at a pace like I’m shoving a cupcake into my mouth in three bites. which, you know, is great! and means I read a lot! but can mean I miss details, or don’t 
retain 
details, later on. 
(i think this is probably also part of why i’m such a rereader - it’s very rewarding for me even with books that don’t generally get considered to have ‘reread value’.)
so this format forces me to slow down, take in relatively short pieces at a time, which narrows the scope of what I 
can 
pay attention to which means I can notice more details more clearly. and that’s just kinda fun.
(“lise you could do this with other books you read” oh sure but that would require me having a certain kind of self-discipline I simply do not have)
i hope this inspires everyone to collectively watch both Nosferatu films

Dracula Daily

dracula daily is just a ploy to get people to check their emails
I was wondering why everyone was talking about Dracula on here. But because I refuse to read any post longer than 5 sentences, I just thought you were all being weird.

So everyone is talking about Jonathan Harker from Dracula being really unaware of the fact he’s in a horror novel, probably due to that Dracula daily thing. So now I got to defend my boy. 
So the vibe I’ve always gotten from the opening bit with Jonathan was less “the character who doesn’t realize what genre they are in” and more “huh, these sure are a lot of horror red flags. Odd. But this is the real world so I’m just being paranoid. Now I’ll continue with what I was doing- huh, weird. That’s another horror flag. Mina will love hearing about how odd this trip has been so far” 
But then he just keeps tripping over horror flags until he eventually realizes he actually IS in a horror novel. 
I actually find this a much better alternative to the oblivious horror protagonist trope, because obviously if a real person started encountering horror red flags like that in the real world they would be creeped out but ultimately continue with their day because this is the real world and real people don’t get eaten by monsters. Sure, some of us would just nope right out of there because we aren’t taking that chance. But ultimately Jonathan isn’t a superstitious person, so while he notices the bad omens accumulating around him he dismisses them at first because to do otherwise would be foolish in his mind. Especially because if he just leaves without an actually good reason he’ll probably be fired from what is presumably a very well paying job. I mean he’s literally being paid to go meet foreign royalty and help them buy some property. If I was sent to help the queen of England purchase an American beach house I couldn’t just leave and tell my boss that the queen definitely wanted to eat me, that would be crazy. 
So tl:dr cut my boi Jonathan some slack. It’s not that he’s unaware he’s in a horror novel. It’s that he’s unaware he’s a fictional character in the first place.

body: Thanks to Dracula Daily and tumblrs new obsession with Dracula I was reminded of Schoolyard Heroes

You know I read dracula in high school. I imagined this would be similar to in school where I kept having to write down the dates to match it up because my brain hated the non linear aspect. (Literally had a sheet labeled BDA- before dracula arrival and ADA-after dracula arrival and AFA-after first attack.)
I knew it was in chronological order, I just expected it to be incomprehensible in that specific manner. And I am so happy its 100% actually easier to read and flows just fine. 
Also reading this on the tail end of reading Hunger Pangs after finally managing to get it onto my ancient nook and while running three CoS games is amazing because:
1. I knew Dracula was a pervasive influence over most vampire media that was good. I am being slapped in the face once more with just how blatant some of that influence is and it is delicious.
2. I remember next to nothing of the plot. Where did all my memories of the actual contents of the book go? All I remember is extreme frustration and annoyance at trying to figure out what the hell was going on.
3. Unintentionally being reminded of being in school. I loved vampires even then and the amazing librarians there would hold new vampire fiction hostage from me until I read another chapter of Dracula because 'trust me you will thank me later.' (I did. They were great.)
4. Dracula is confusing as hell in non chronological order. I don't think we actually meet the man in person in the normal way of reading it until at least a third of the way in.

anyway yeah keep making memes theyre hilarious i just wanted to add a lil bit of cultural context
body:
so i'm enjoying watching people go through the dracula daily thing but i wanted y'all to know (extremely light spoilers)
that if it was written today, Dracula would 100% be classified as Urban Fantasy and Magical Realism and not just a monster horror story
like bram stoker put a shitton of research into the book, and gave the characters all kinds of brand new advanced tech. the blood transfusion scene, for example, is interesting because blood transfusions had been successfully performed for decades but it still wasn't fully understood why they sometimes failed. by the 1890s--when he was writing--doctors had discovered platelets but hadn't developed anticoagulants. they knew that transfusing blood could kill a patient if a clot wound up in their brain or lungs, but there wasn't a foolproof method of preventing clots. the method used in Dracula was a cutting-edge (sorry) (no im not) experimental procedure that simply didn't allow the blood to meet the air, by directly linking the donor's artery to the recipient's vein. this showed a lot of promise in animal trials but never caught on in human treatments because it's basically impossible to measure how much blood is being transfused, so you could wind up killing both donor (via exsanguination) and recipient (via Too Much Fuckin' Blood) in one fell swoop.
additionally, blood types weren't discovered until a few years 
after 
the publication of Dracula, which i imagine really pissed bram stoker off. it would've been SUPER FITTING and ROMANTIC to add the detail that the character who donates their blood HAS to be the one, because they're THE ONLY ONE OF THE GOOD GUYS WITH THE SAME BLOOD TYPE AS THE VICTIM, which proves their love is TRUE and MEANT TO BE and DESTINED BY GOD and all that other late 19th century gothic romance shit

body:
i don't know, if i was a vampire i would keep my coffin. i might not sleep in it but i would keep it. maybe i would sleep in it, haven't decided yet. but i imagine that i couldn't go back to my family, i'd just be stuck, and that coffin is what they buried me in. the people who loved me, who said goodbye to me, who thought i was gone forever, they chose this coffin to put me in. they wanted to protect me from the dirt and the bugs and they wanted to do something nice for me, something that they thought i would never notice. but i noticed! i'm a vampire! i can see the coffin. and maybe it's a cheap one they got on sale, maybe that's a slight against me, in which case maybe they didn't love me so much and i wouldn't keep it, but that's not a fun thought experiment. maybe it was the best one they could get for me. maybe they made it themselves, carving out one last piece of art for me, a gift that would rot in the dirt and mud with me, something my dead eyes could never see, my cold hands could never touch. but im not really dead! i can see it! i can touch it! i can love their love and i can feel their grief. i can touch my name, a marker for them, for me, so that i wouldn't be forgotten, so that people would know who was buried. so that i would be remembered. i would keep my coffin to remember them back. to remember how they loved me, so much so that they did one final act of kindness to protect me, even though it didn't matter anymore. 
anyway dracula daily has really made me think about the implications of vampires lol

body:
I think part of the reason Dracula Daily works so well is because Stoker is, given all of the allowances of the time, a fairly good writer. He's descriptive but doesn't indulge too much (if you've read other literature of the time you know - this is the age of writers getting paid a dime a word). The suspence buildup during all of the coach ride(s) is very well made. The setting feels rooted in reality despite the hints of supernatural stuff. The mixture of charming and repulsive in Dracula himself still gets to me - it's an effect many writers have tried to achieve and failed.
Also, for all that we are meming poor Jonathan to death, his hesitation feels reasonable to me. I mean: he's in a foreign country where he doesn't speak the language, in an extremely isolated place to booth, with no maps or knowledge of the area at all. What is he supposed to do besides following the itinerary that has been prepared for him so graciously by this Count, who has very obviously spent a ton of money on this deal? Let's say he decides to go back to England - what is he gonna say to his boss, that he got spooked and ran off and ruined the biggest deal ever for both of them? He's gonna get fired just after passing the bar exam! And what of poor Mina! 
It's like haunted house stories: people are like "why didn't they move???" but like telling your bank "hey remember the house you gave us a mortgage on, well it's haunted, we need to leave it and buy another immediately" isn't exactly going to work, is it? We *know* they are in an horror story, but the characters don't! 
I'm not trying to stop you tho, the memes are hilarious, keep them coming, I'm just saying: while you read, suspend your disbelief a little, it will make the experience more rewarding.

body:
One thing that I’ve only noticed because of 
Dracula Daily
 is how Jonathan Harker is so English he refuses to acknowledge that he’s somewhere with a different calendar. They’re still using the Julian calendar in Transylvania because of the Orthodox church, so for them it was late April and St George’s Day, but he’s all “no, it is early May on my proper Englishman’s calendar as used by proper people”.

body:
My friend just told me a hilarious-in-hindsight story in which she
traveled to a foreign city for work and arrived exhausted
got picked up by an incredibly sketch cab, but didn't feel like she could back out because he had already loaded up her bags
instead texted her husband with the license plate number in case she disappeared 
got offered a bottle of water by the aforementioned extremely sketch driver, to which she was like ".......yeah no"
got worried that she was being driven off somewhere to be murdered so brought up google maps to make sure they were going the right direction
(had no clear idea of what to do if they weren't)
...and ultimately arrived safely at her next airport
Anyway I think maybe we need to cut our mutual friend Jonathan a little more slack because apparently there was nothing at all unrealistic about his May 5th account and behavior
